# Major 7th Chord in B (A Shape)

The Major 7th chord is a commonly used chord in music. When played using the A shape in the key of B, it creates a rich and mellow sound that can add a sophisticated touch to your music. In this reference sheet, we will explore the notes and intervals that make up the Major 7th chord in the key of B using the A shape on the guitar.

## Notes and Intervals
The Major 7th chord in B using the A shape consists of the following notes and intervals:
- B (Root)
- D# (Major 3rd)
- F# (Perfect 5th)
- A# (Major 7th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Major 7th chord in B using the A shape is often used in jazz, R&B, and soul music. It adds a sophisticated and jazzy flavor to compositions, creating a sense of warmth and richness in the music. This chord is often used to add color and tension, leading to a more complex and interesting harmonic palette.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the Major 7th chord in B (A shape) effectively:
1. **"Fly Me to the Moon"** by Frank Sinatra - This jazz standard features the Major 7th chord extensively, adding a romantic and nostalgic feel to the song.
2. **"Fallin'"** by Alicia Keys - This R&B hit uses the Major 7th chord to create a soulful and emotional sound that complements the heartfelt lyrics.
3. **"Don't Know Why"** by Norah Jones - This jazz-pop ballad makes use of the Major 7th chord in a relaxed and laid-back manner, enhancing the intimate atmosphere of the song.

These songs showcase how the Major 7th chord in B using the A shape can be utilized to evoke various emotions and moods in different musical contexts.
